audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a distinct, mechanical sound, resembling that of a race car engine. Subsequently, a male speaker begins to explain a class where students are expected to be both uncreative and unoriginal. He further elaborates that if students exhibit creativity or originality, they are marked down, and as a result, they learn to be uncreative.

The audio features a single male speaker, discussing the act of appropriating and plagiarizing, emphasizing that they should not write anything original. The speaker mentions claiming texts as their own and then comments on how his students are already good writers, so he doesn't need to make them better.

The clip begins with one male speaker discussing "bad stealers," noting they have been stealing for a long time without thinking about what they steal or why. He says this forces them to "theorize their theft" and become "smarter and better." The clip ends abruptly without any background noise or music.

The clip starts with a male speaker who suggests that nobody is original anymore, and should not be. He argues that progress comes from combining pre-existing information, implying that there is no going back. This is followed by the sound of a train, which dominates the audio suggesting movement and transportation.

The audio clip begins with a conversation. A male speaker admits to not writing anything original, stating "I don't write my own books." He then elaborates on his process of becoming interested in something and transcribing or copying it. The soundscape shifts to a faster-tempo, electronic, music, its mood driving and intense.  The male speaker returns, discussing authorship and the changing nature of genius. He compares the modern author to a hip-hop DJ, saying that the person has the best samples, and then is considered the best DJ. He states that writing paradigm is moving forward by the means of the hip hop DJ. The clip concludes with the continued electronic music.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who begins by remarking, "In 1959 a poet named Brian Gysin," further elaborating on the fact that "poetry was 50 years behind painting." He speaks with a thoughtful and somewhat academic tone, emphasizing that "the art world has long been open to other strategies" and mentioning appropriation. The speaker contrasts this openness with the writing and music worlds, using the example of samples.

The clip starts with a male speaker commenting on how literature is "just getting to it" and implementing a "Duchampian strategy," suggesting it's slow and "pretty far behind right now." The audio then transitions abruptly to a louder ambience featuring the sounds of a moving vehicle or machinery, seemingly indicative of an outdoor or industrial setting.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining that certain elements are part of uncreative writing, different strategies within it. He then states what is not part of uncreative writing is pastiche or "taking a line from here or there", clarifying "that's not plagiarism".

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing plagiarism, distinguishing it from appropriation as taking something in its entirety and changing its context. His tone is explanatory and somewhat academic. The speech then fades out, transitioning into ambient sounds suggesting a train in motion, characterized by rhythmic, consistent sounds. This background noise is shortly accompanied by music, a somewhat dissonant and unsettling piece possibly in the experimental genre, which features industrial sounds alongside traditional musical elements.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a consensual activity, mentioning an "S&M club" and emphasizing that "nobody gets hurt." His tone is explanatory and slightly defensive. The speech is followed by a musical interlude, featuring a distorted electronic sound resembling a train whistle. This is layered over ambient background sounds that suggest an urban environment.

The clip begins with speech. A male speaker, with a somewhat somber tone, expresses his opinion that "we can't understand audience anymore." He continues, explaining how he feels there was a time when an audience could be assumed, but now the audience is "so big and so thin" that it's difficult to know who they're speaking to, and that he doesn't think anyone's paying attention. This is accompanied by a prominent vehicle sound, which suggests an outdoor setting.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing people paying attention to "headlines and tweets" and things that "move very quickly" but not engaging with content as they once did. He states he doesn't think that's good or bad and that there's "no point complaining about it" since it's the way it is. Background noise, characterized by consistent and moderate volume, can be heard throughout the clip.

The audio clip begins with speech, a male voice explaining his preference to adjust to a situation, considering it "my problem, not the media" or "culture's problem". This is followed by the sound of a vehicle, likely an automobile, characterized by engine noise, which possibly indicates traffic. Then there's a shift back to speech, another male voice clarifying that he writes "the text of my daily online routine".

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the nature of personal memoirs in relation to browser history. His tone is casual and conversational. He then notes that he is practically always online and feels "dead" when disconnected. After this, we hear the sound of tires rolling against pavement. Returning to the man, he discusses how memories are stored digitally on hard drives, the cloud, and social media. He seems unworried about remembering things, stating that "everything is archived now." He concludes that he can "google my memories" better than he can remember them himself, implying that he no longer needs to keep memories in his head.
